description.narrative: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

Increase the availability and use of proven life-saving interventions that address the major killers of mothers and children and improve their health and nutrition status, including effective maternity care and management of obstetric complications; prevention services including newborn care, routine immunization, polio eradication, safe water and hygiene, and micronutrients; improved maternal, infant and young child feeding; and treatment of life-threatening childhood illnesses.

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Enhance the capacity of businesses and business associations in terms of their corporate governance capabilities and their application of best practices and technologies to achieve increased production and marketing of products and services. It includes adoption of efficient production processes, improved labor productivity, environmentally-sound management of natural resources and the development of accounting and management systems that can help the company and industry group implement business, labor, product and process standards that enhance business competitiveness. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

Special Self Help-Burundi

Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

description.narrative: (Burundi): Tubiteho, receives Malaria, Maternal Child Health (MCH), and Family Planning (FP) funds and it targets 16 districts in six provinces (390 facilities) and works at the facility and community level. FY22 malaria funds will improve malaria prevention and treatment among pregnant women and children under-five by promoting the routine distribution and use of ITNs during ante-natal care (ANC) and immunization visits. The quality of case management at the facility and community levels will be strengthened. Social and behavior change will focus on early care seeking and proper use of bed nets. FY22 MCH funds will improve access and quality of MCH services and strengthen the capacity of health district teams and health providers to improve oversight and quality of treatment: to integrate and scale-up high-impact interventions, to provide key medical equipment, to integrate the prevention of Mother-To-Child [HIV] Transmission (PMTCT) with MCH services, and to build the capacity of community health workers (CHWs) to carry out SBC interventions, monitoring ANC and delivery at the clinical level with skilled birth attendants, and community maternal death. Integrated Community Case Management (ICCM) will focus on the prevention and treatment of malaria, diarrhea, pneumonia, and FP to reduce their burden on child morbidity and mortality. FY22 FP funds will continue supporting on-site training of service providers to improve their competencies to offer contraceptive methods; support MOH to develop new strategies to improve access and the use of FP services by adolescents and youth, and the Ministry of Education's mentoring programs that provide adolescent girls with FP/RH information and counseling that are needed to reduce dropouts due to pregnancy; to strengthen approaches to increase the modern contraceptive prevalence rate (PPFP and the integration of FP with other health and USAID BHA activities targeting the internally displaced population, refugees, and retur

title.narrative: Strengthening the National Response to Trafficking in Persons Prevention, Victim Protection and Prosecution in Burundi

description.narrative: (Burundi): ..In 2019, to help the GOB make progress on.addressing trafficking in persons (TIP), USAID awarded a grant to the.International Organization for Migration (IOM) to support the "Strengthening.the National Response to Trafficking in Persons' Prevention, Victim Protection,.and Prosecution" activity in Burundi, and another to UNICEF.to implement the "Enhancing the Monitoring of Child's Rights Violations and.Human Trafficking Victims in Burundi." Starting.in 2015 and for six consecutive years, Burundi had been classified as a Tier 3.country under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 (TVPA). In.2021, the TIP report upgraded Burundi to Tier 2 Watchlist, and then in 2022 to.Tier 2. This improvement in TIP categorization is a result of increased.investigations, prosecutions, and convictions of trafficking crimes, including.by allegedly complicit officials. For example, the GOB took steps to.increase protections for Burundian migrants abroad, including by establishing.bilateral agreements with key destination countries...FY 2022.funding will continue to support the GOB to sustain and build on gains realized.to date and to focus efforts in areas where the GOB must still meet minimum.standards. Examples include screening for key indicators of trafficking.among vulnerable populations; providing training to increase awareness among.law enforcement and judicial officials on the 2014 Anti-Trafficking Act and.investigating and prosecuting trafficking cases; and improving GOB oversight of.labor recruitment companies, thereby holding fraudulent labor recruiters.criminally accountable...These.FY 2022 funds satisfy the required $500,000 TIP directive, which is part of.USAID Democracy funds. ..The.activity is aligned with the BNDP and the Embassy's ICS Mission Goal 3, Invest.in Society, and the Region: Burundi is a peaceful, open, and stable actor at.home and in the region... .

title.narrative: Enhancing the Monitoring and Reporting of Childrens Rights Violations and Human Trafficking Victims Activity

description.narrative: (Burundi): .For five years, Burundi's classification under the Trafficking Victims Prevention Act of 2000 (TVPA) has remained at the Tier 3 level, with children included among the victims of trafficking. FY20 funds will support the follow-on to UNICEF's "Enhancing the Monitoring and Reporting of Children's Rights Violations and Human Trafficking Victims Activity that developed a monitoring and reporting system to report abuse and violations against children, built a network of children rights monitors with at least one per commune, and achieved a decrease in incidences of violence against children in Burundi. Building on this, UNICEF is working to strengthen the capacity of the local network and is gradually transferring full implementation responsibilities to an association of national organizations with programs focusing on child rights-FENADEB (Federation Nationale des Associations Chargees de la Defense des Droits de l'Enfant au Burundi)-through hands-on capacity building. In FY20, this activity adapted its training and interventions with FENADEB and the local monitors to capture cases in the new context where violence is reported in homes, schools, and communities, and to include documentation on trafficking in persons (TIP). UNICEF will also support data collection on children's rights violations with a focus on TIP to help the Government of Burundi achieve compliance with TVPA. These efforts will further Burundi's capacity to identify child victims of trafficking, put preventive measures in place to prevent further trafficking, and help in bringing cases against perpetrators so they can be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. The activity is aligned with the 2018-2027 Burundi National Development Plan and the Embassy's ICS Mission Objective of increased Burundian understanding of and transparent adherence to international human rights standards and the rule of law..

title.narrative: WIYIZIRE (Come here, we will support you) Health Activity

description.narrative: WIYIZIRE (come here, we will support you) has the primary goal of reducing and mitigating orphans and vulnerable childrens (OVC) human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) risk, supporting case-finding of HIV-positive OVC, and strengthening linkages with clinical HIV services, with a focus on prevention of sexual violence and new HIV infections. Achievement of the activity goal will require a multipronged approach to increase access to and use of HIV and health services, increase access to HIV and violence prevention interventions, and improve school progression and economic stability for vulnerable children and their households.

The objective of GIRITEKA (Be Respected) is to improve the integration of gender-based violence (GBV) prevention and response into the HIV clinical cascade to accelerate progress towards control of the HIV epidemic and, more specifically, to address GBV, a key structural driver of the HIV epidemic. Three intermediate results will support achievement of this objective: 1) Improved GBV and HIV prevention for vulnerable and key populations; 2) Improved GBV case-identification and response in HIV index testing and partner notification; 3) Improved post-GBV care integrated into HIV clinical services

description.narrative: The purpose of the SIMS contract is to conduct SIMS site assessments to collect data on quality of clinical services, community-based services, and health systems strengthening interventions.

The urisanze ("feel at home") activity will increase access to comprehensive hiv prevention, care, and treatment services, and strengthen systems for planning, monitoring, evaluating, and assure the quality of services along the prevention-to-care continuum for key populations.

ABANDI (act as you do for others) activity will increase access to comprehensive HIV prevention, care, and treatment services, and strengthen systems for planning, monitoring, evaluating, and assure the quality of services along the prevention-to-care continuum for men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender individuals (TG).

The cooperative agreement aims to mitigate orphans' and vulnerable children's (OVC) human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) risk while ensuring that children are healthy, safe, schooled and nourished and their households are economically stable and resilient. The activity will specifically address key gaps that include case-finding of HIV-positive OVC, and strengthening linkages with clinical HIV services, adherence to treatment, and viral load coverage as well as malnutrition. Also, the activity will focus on improving OVC's safety by preventing and responding to gender-based violence (GBV) with a focus on girls and boys ages 9-14 years old, who are more vulnerable and at higher risk for GBV.

This activity seeks to address remaining challenges and close persistent gaps to achieve the UNSAIDS 95-95-95 goals and therefore reach and sustain HIV/AIDS epidemic control in burundi. it will set up interventions to strengthen the health system and to improve community engagement, building on best practices from other pepfar activities implemented to date. The activity will complement existing USAID/Burundi clinical, community health, and social-behavior services delivery activities.

description.narrative: Improve the capacity of businesses to integrate into domestic and international markets through increases in productivity and improvements in corporate governance and the development and application of modern technology and marketing practices. Business capacity development programs may include activities that help men- and women-owned firms and associations respond to these international markets and create regional alliances.

title.narrative: Roads to a Healthy Future II (ROADS II) - Burundi

description.narrative: In Burundi, the Roads to a Healthy Future (ROADS II) project is designed to increase access to high-quality facility- and community-based HIV and broader health services for mobile populations and local residents living in Karusi, Kayanza, Kirundo and Muyinga provinces and the capital city, Bujumbura. The project, which is funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, works with pregnant women; populations at risk of contracting HIV, including long-distance drivers, female sex workers and other groups; people living with HIV; and orphans and other vulnerable children. ROADS II also works to strengthen the integration of HIV, family planning and reproductive health services. The project has a strong gender-based violence component to address structural barriers that prevent women from accessing services.

Promote peaceful agreement on democratic reform, rules, and frameworks. Promote peaceful, broad-based participation in determining, defining, and negotiating changes to governing structures. Illustrative examples include promoting inclusive consensus-building processes related to peace agreements, national dialogues, referenda on key issues, and constitutional development or reform. Programs are designed to incorporate and support mechanisms that advance conflict mediation, resolution and negotiation of disputes in the context of these processes.

Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

description.narrative: (Burundi): The Integrated Health Project strengthens the health system, community, and civil society's capacity to deliver quality reproductive, maternal, neonatal and child health (RMNCH), malaria, and HIV/AIDS services to reduce maternal and child morbidity and mortality, as well as malaria and HIV disease burdens. FY17 funds will be utilized as follows:..Malaria: Support community health workers testing and treating malaria and provide malaria prevention messaging. Improve the uptake of malaria prevention services, build capacity in diagnosis, prevention, treatment, and management of the supply chain for health care workers. Support outreach sites for testing and treatment...RMNCH: Provide basic and comprehensive emergency obstetric and newborn care to prevent hemorrhaging (cause of maternal mortality), improve essential newborn care and family planning services, and strengthen the integration of prevention services for malaria during pregnancy and mother to child transmission of HIV.

title.narrative: Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) Acceleration Project

description.narrative: The Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) Acceleration project, funded by the U.S. Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, aims to scale up quickly high-quality facility-based and community-based PMTCT services in four provinces of Burundi: Bujumbura City, Bujumbura Rural, Gitega and Ngozi. The project also focuses on preventing HIV in women of childbearing age, decreasing unwanted pregnancies among women with HIV, and providing care and support for women, infants and families living with HIV.

title.narrative: Dukire Tubane Lets Heal and Live Together

description.narrative: (Burundi): In September 2020, USAID funded the "Improving dialogue and social cohesion among political leaders and communities in Burundi," a new component to an already existing Catholic Relief Services (CRS)-implemented activity, Dukire Tubane (Let Us Heal and Live Together), which seeks to reduce youth involvement in political violence by promoting social cohesion, trauma healing, and economic strengthening. The new component was funded for 12 months and strengthened an existing advocacy network in the Inter Religious Council of Burundi (CICB) to play a mediating role among political actors, mitigate lingering political tensions from the May 2020 elections, and prevent related violence among communities. FY 2021 funds will extend this activity for an additional two years to strengthen the network's expansion to local communities. During the extension, USAID investment will support the fight against GBV cases arising from social disagreements and domestic and intimate partner violence by extending training on a proven model that focuses on household communication to prevent violence between young couples, thus contributing to the GBV directive. This activity supports U.S. Embassy Bujumbura ICS Goal 1 to address underlying drivers of conflict that make Burundi vulnerable to instability, including lack of economic opportunity as well as social divisions, governance, and human rights challenges; and Mission Objective 1.3 to increase Burundian understanding of and transparent adherence to international human rights standards and the rule of law...

title.narrative: Prevention of Mother To Child Transmission (PMTCT) Activity

description.narrative: The goal of the activity is that PMTCT and antiretroviral therapy (ART) services in three of the highest prevalence provinces are scale-up to achieve epidemic control nationally. The project aims to increase coverage throughout the full PMTCT care cascade to ensure that 95-100% of all pregnant women utilizing ante-natal care (ANC), labor and delivery, or post-partum care services know their HIV status, 95-100% of those who are HIV positive are placed on lifelong ART, and that at least 50% of male partners and 90% of children of women testing positive are also tested and brought into the HIV care and treatment cascade.

The objective of the Reaching an AIDS-Free Generation Activity is to scale up antiretroviral therapy (ART) services for people living with HIV using an integrated, community-based approach in high-prevalence provinces to contribute towards the Government of Burundi's goal to achieve epidemic control nationally.

description.narrative: Support and strengthen the negotiation process and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. For a peace/negotiations process to have a chance of success, it must entail building trust in the process, between parties, and among their constituents, with a special focus on including women. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesmen engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to bring them closer to their constituencies.

title.narrative: Burundians Responding against Violence and Inequality (BRAVI)

description.narrative: (Burundi): BRAVI works to improve sexual and gender-based violence prevention and response efforts, including the provision of integrated family planning (FP) and sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) services. BRAVI trains providers to recognize, screen for and respond to, the needs of SGBV survivors and to respond to their sexual and reproductive health needs, including FP needs of survivors of SGBV. at the community level, this includes gender-sensitive workshops and engaging community leaders in FP promotion efforts, raising FP awareness, including around method options, as well as addressing the harmful social and cultural norms that permit SGBV to occur in the first place..FY17 funds will be used to integrate provision of FP services in response efforts to SGBV through training and sensitization of health providers, cross-sectoral coordination, scaling up good practices and lessons learned to ensure all survivors of SGBV have access to FP services and to modern contraceptive methods.

Supports the following illustrative program-funded costs: salaries of US, FSN, and TCN and other staff such as PSCs, RSSAs, PASAs, CASUs working for the US Government managing, administering, and supporting programs and their program-funded benefits such as housing, travel, transportation, education allowances etc; institutional contractors that provide such staff, rent, IT services, the program-funded share of utilities, staff training costs and the cost of developing and administering training programs, equipment and supplies, ICASS, vehicle fuel and maintenance, maintenance contracts, janitorial services, operational unit web page development and maintenance, outreach such as publications and the cost of their preparation (including staff costs), and technical assistance to ensure USG compliance with regulations.

description.narrative: To promote transparency and participation in the policy process, USAIDs Burundi Policy Reform Program strengthened public dialogue and relationships among the government, civil society, and the media. The program also improved the effectiveness of policy development and implementation to assist the overall political process. Through training, policy discussions, and grant-making, Chemonics and USAID built the capacity of government, civil society, and media to understand and discuss policy matters in an informed and inclusive manner. Policy areas focused on issues related to land, water, and good governance.
